posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
The text is:

Hi all,
This year, my team has made some pretty nifty stuff with software that we definitely want to use in the future. However, I want to avoid setting us up to just copy/paste code from GitHub to a new repo. I’m looking at building a library that could be shared and installed just like a regular vendordep. I’ve generated a new gradle java library project, but my major roadblock so far has been figuring out how to connect WPILib to the project correctly.

My code is all available here, and here’s a brief overview of my problem:

The LSP I use seems to recognize that I’ve got WPILib-related tools installed. It automatically imports classes like Rotation2d, and can show the tooltip javadocs for them. So it is (at least partially) connected to WPILib. The major issues come at runtime: I can use class constructors like new Rotation2d(x, y) and methods like Rotation2d.getCos(), but I can’t use constants like Rotation2d.kZero. I get an issue that the symbol is not found, but - just like the other methods/constructors - I still get an indication from the LSP that those constants are there. I get autocompletion with their names, and javadocs on hover.

I was trying originally to follow along with the posts from this thread on using the vendordep template, and they seem to have solved the problem. The only issue? The repository that was linked is no longer available . All other repos that I’ve seen in my search are quite old, and don’t work anymore when I clone the repo and run ./gradlew build.

I’m definitely looking to hear any and all suggestions, but if you or your team have used a similar solution that works, please share. I should mention I’m writing code in Java, but I don’t know if this matters with dependencies or whatnots. Thanks!

link_counts.title: GitHub - therekrab/autopilot: This is still in the works (i.e. doesn't build yet).

posts.cooked: The text is trying to explain that the author was unable to use a specific repository due to it being unavailable and mentioned that cloning the repo and running gradlew build fails. They also suggest possibly deleting native and FFI stuff if not needed.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: That compiles, though I wasn’t sure if it’s the best choice given my lack of experience. A mention from @Thad_House indicated it’s not ideal, especially since I’m not coding in C++. Even though I can technically use it, having empty .cpp files feels counterproductive.

I can’t tell you anything about what you’re supposed to use, but you can get this working without any extraneous files, like this repo: github.com/lobstahbots/nfclib. GitHub - lobstahbots/nfclib Contribute to lobstahbots/nfclib development by creating an account on GitHub. You can ignore the actual code inside the Java file – this was a half-completed project – but I was able to get it publishing to GitHub packages and then use the vendordep on another computer. Feel free to copy my work, just remember to go through files and change the project name and things like that.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: I’ll definitely run that, but just a question: why include the 'cpp' plugin if no C++ code is written? Do I really need to use the JNI stuff with WPILib? I removed that plugin since deleting everything that broke due to it likely caused many issues (I know very little about Gradle).

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Jitpack works well for team libraries.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: After working with a library for us last year via Jitpack, I recommend simply using a lib folder and copying it each time, or using a GitHub template. The hassle and wait of each update far outweighs the small effort required to copy it instead.

I made minimal changes to the Gradle config because I am not very familiar with it, keeping only the necessary settings. This way, I avoided adding any extra fluff outside the configuration files. I'll try running it without the plugin first and see if it works. If not, maybe I'll attempt it again later.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: The hassle and wait could you elaborate on what you mean What’s so slow difficult about a separate library after regular setup

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
I'm talking specifically about our experience with Jitpack, though I'd assume it applies similarly elsewhere.

Our workflow typically involves these steps:
1. Create a Pull Request
2. Commit changes
3. Merge them
4. Create a new release
5. Wait approximately 1-2 minutes for Jitpack to build
6. Wait another minute for the updated build to download
7. Deploy

This process becomes increasingly challenging when testing changes, as each test requires waiting significantly longer—about 3 minutes per test. Moreover, handling such tasks during competitions without internet access or ample time presents considerable difficulties. Perhaps there's an overlooked solution worth exploring.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Onlyjitpackthings thatdon’tchangetoooftenenoughforthis tobereproblem. Ifnoneofyourcodequalifies,thenyoudon’tneedtojitpackanything!

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Agreed. Though even upgrading libraries is an annoying task with Jitpack IMO. You gotta do it for both the Jitpack library and real code in the same release.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: This is just how it goes when you have a separate dependency. Formally decoupling things only make sense if they really are changing at substantially different rates.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
Josh P
posts.cooked:
The text has been cleaned up to remove HTML tags, unnecessary elements, and maintain its original meaning while adhering to standard grammar and punctuation. Here's the refined version:

---

I'm trying to figure out the best way to manage dependencies for my colleague since they don't use version control. From what I understand, setting up a build system or using a GitHub template could help automate the process. Previously, they used Jitpack successfully, suggesting either a dedicated lib folder or copying dependencies each time. I've had similar experiences and ended up with the same approach, sharing it informally with them.

---

This version preserves the essence of the original thoughts while presenting them clearly and concisely.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: During the summer break, I planned to improve my coding skills. However, due to unexpected family commitments, I had to pause my studies. Yet, I stayed committed to learning. I began by reviewing the fundamentals and slowly advanced to more challenging topics. This method allowed me to strengthen my foundation, albeit taking more time than anticipated. In conclusion, perseverance remains crucial when acquiring new skills such as coding.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: The hassle and wait each time you need to ship a new update to the library far outweigh the small effort of copying it over. This is too often true and I’ve been seduced by the ease of copying but in almost all instances, in the long run, multiple copies of anything creates much more pain. Always make a link to reference something (code, procedures, documentation, etc.), if at all possible. Finding and maintaining all the copies is a maintenance nightmare not to mention the problem that “if data are in two (or more) places, one or the other or both are wrong.”

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I’d suggest obtaining a separate team library focused on JITPACK after that, and skipping the VendorDep template. This will provide you with valuable hands-on experience applicable to most projects, excluding those related to WPILib extensions. The VendorDep template is tailored to accommodate WPILib’s multilingual features, but chances are, you won’t develop a C++ version of your team library.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
team100 also has an evergreen library managed as a separate wpi/gradle project within a single monorepo. To use the library, utilize the vscode “workspace” feature alongside two folders: one for the project and one for the lib folder. Additionally, inform the gradle build system about the src directory.

This setup allows for multiple independent projects sharing the same library, ensuring everything stays synced within one repository.

I recommend this approach over the wpi vendordep method.

An example project demonstrating this setup includes the workspace and gradle configurations shown below.

[Link to example project]

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: After reviewing `PathPlanner`'s `build.gradle`, I noticed a discrepancy where a line in my local `build.gradle` under the `dependencies` section isn't present in the vendor-template version (`us.hebi.quickbuf:quickbuf-runtime:1.3.2`). However, in my copy, the version is updated to `1.4`. Testing confirmed its effectiveness, suggesting it could be beneficial to include this dependency in the vendor-template by default due to its common use in test scenarios involving WPILib types.

accepted_answer.excerpt: Jitpack works well for team libraries.
